questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents for bedwetting. He went 3 months without wetting the bed but then started again 6 weeks ago. He has been wetting the bed about 1–2 times per week. He has not had daytime urinary incontinence. His teachers report that he is attentive in preschool and plays well with his peers. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance Nocturnal enuresis is defined as involuntary nighttime bedwetting in children more than or equal to 5 years of age . Bedwetting is not considered abnormal in children less than 5 years so no treatment is required, only reassurance.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Desmopressin therapy is initiated after initial therapy of behavioral medication in nocturnal enuresis. Since bedwetting is not abnormal in this patient so not indicated. Option: B. Enuresis alarms are first-line of treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction, and motivational therapy). Option: C. Oxybutynin is also a 2nd line drug for nocturnal enuresis .

questions.text: MMSE or Mini-mental state examination is used to diagnose cognitive impairment by 5 different tests. All are true about evaluating in the Mini-mental state examination, except?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is asked the time of the month or which place he is in to know his orientation

options.label: B
options.text: He is asked to recall a few words that the examiner had said a while ago

options.label: C
options.text: The patient is asked to spell a known word to assess his attention

options.label: D
options.text: EEG is done to see the generalized slowing of waves

questions.correct_answer: D. EEG is done to see the generalized slowing of waves
questions.explanation:
Solution:

EEG is done to see the generalized slowing of waves EEG is not a part of MMSE.

Highyeild:

MMSE assessed 5 cognitions: Orientation – 10 Registration – 3 Recall-3 Attention-5 Language-9 Total of 30 points Anything less than 24 suggests cognitive impairment.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. The patient is asked about the time of the month or which place he is in to know his orientation. It is done to access the orientation and points are given out of 10. Option: B. He is asked to recall a few words that the examiner had said a while ago. It is done to access recall. 3 points are given to this part. Option: C. The patient is asked to spell a known word to assess his attention. 9 points are allocated to access attention and concentration.

questions.text: The 3.5-year-old boy is brought by his father with behavioral issues. He reports that for the past month, after the patient goes to bed and sleep, the parents hear him get up in the middle of the night and find crying and seemingly disoriented with rapid breathing and profuse sweating. In the morning, he wakes up in his usual happy mood and does not remember what occurred the previous evening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sleep terror disorder This patient's presentation is typical for sleep terror disorder It typically manifests itself as emotional and behavioral disturbances at night. These events usually occur early in the nightly sleep cycle during delta (slow-wave) sleep. With sleep terror disorder, the affected child does not remember the episodes in the morning.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Nightmares -The individual wakes from nocturnal sleep or naps with detailed and vivid recall or intensely frightening dreams , usually involving threats to survival, security, or self-esteem . Option: C. Somnambulism is sleep-w alking. Option: D. Insomnia- is difficulty in falling asleep.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes as she is having trouble staying awake in the evening and gets tired unusually early in the evenings and has trouble staying awake through dinner. She also experiences increased daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She typically goes to bed around 9 PM and gets out of bed between 2 and 3 AM. She does not have any trouble falling asleep. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Advanced sleep phase disorder Advanced sleep phase disorder is a circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder in which the sleep-wake cycle begins and ends earlier than normal.

Highyeild:

This causes individuals to feel the need to go to bed early and to wake up early in the morning irrespective of when they go to bed. A patient who delays going to bed will therefore not get an adequate quantity of sleep, resulting in daytime sleepiness. Advanced sleep phase disorder is frequently associated with older age .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Patients with delayed sleep phase disorder would have excessive daytime sleepiness if they forced themselves to wake up before the end of their sleep-wake cycle. Individuals go to bed later than normal (usually 1-4 AM), and would not result in excessive sleepiness in the evening. Option: C. Early sleep onset and early awakening are some of the changes in sleep patterns that occur as a part of the normal aging process . However, these changes would not be accompanied by symptoms such as daytime sleepiness and unusual tiredness in the evenings . Option: D. Hypersomnolence disorder can only be diagnosed if the patient has symptoms of unusual sleepiness despite at least 7 hours of uninterrupted sleep (this patient has a night-time sleep duration of 5-6 hours).

Extraedge:

Other features of hypersomnolence disorder are sleep inertia and prolonged sleep . The onset of hypersomnolence disorder usually occurs between the ages of 15 and 25 years.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is brought by her husband because of difficulty sleeping for the last 2 years which occurred gradually. She is waking up several times per night and wakes up earlier in the morning and on average, sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She does not take any afternoon naps. Which is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reassurance Changes in sleep architecture that occur naturally with aging include: Increased sleep latency Longer light stages of sleep Increasing frequency of nighttime awakenings Decreased time in the deep sleep phase (stage 3) Shorter REM phases This would be best managed with reassurance and sleep hygiene counseling.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Melatonin is an important hormone for sleep onset, and melatonin levels decrease with aging . In theory, melatonin should decrease sleep latency . Furthermore, this patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal (i.e. less than 30 minutes), and it is unclear how much benefit she would receive. Option: C. Diphenhydramine is potentially inappropriate for patients more than 65 years of age due to its anticholinergic effects that can precipitate delirium, constipation, dry mouth, and urinary retention. Option: D. Bilevel positive airway pressure is a non-invasive form of respiratory support for patients with obstructive sleep apnea . Although this patient has daytime sleepiness and night-time awakenings, she lacks other features of obstructive sleep apnea such as obesity, snoring, hypertension, morning headaches, or awakenings with choking.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought by her parents because of difficulty sleeping. One to two times per week for the past 2 months, she has woken up frightened in the middle of the night, yelling and crying. She recalls that she had a bad dream and looks for ways to delay bedtime in the evenings. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nightmare disorder This patient's recurrent nighttime awakening due to nightmares and memory of her bad dreams the next day are consistent with nightmare disorder . Reassurance is the first-line treatment for mild cases of nightmare disorder.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Like the girl in question, patients with sleep terror disorder also experience nightmares. However, these patients are difficult to rouse from sleep and show autonomic responses to what they are dreaming about such as tachycardia and sweating . They do not generally recall what they dreamed after awakening. Option: C. This girl does not exhibit other criteria of PTSD such as altered reactivity to stimuli or a negative impact on her mood or cognition. Additionally, there is nothing in her history to suggest exposure to a prior traumatic event. Option: D. The frequency of this girl's night-time awakenings and her reduction in sleep quality , as well as increased daytime fatigue , avoidance of bedtime, and negative impact on the family (i.e., night-time disruptions), are not consistent with normal development .

questions.text: Good sleep hygiene includes all of the following except?

options.label: A
options.text: Maintain regular hours of bedtime and arising

options.label: B
options.text: Eat a heavy meal before bedtime to help you sleep

options.label: C
options.text: Keep the bedroom cool, dark, and quiet

options.label: D
options.text: If you are preoccupied or worried about something at bedtime, write it down and deal with it in the morning

questions.correct_answer: B. Eat a heavy meal before bedtime to help you sleep
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eat a heavy meal before bedtime to help you sleep You should avoid eating a heavy meal before going to sleep.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- All other statements are correct regarding good sleep hygiene.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder reports sleep disturbance for 4 weeks. Which of the following is NOT a recognized alteration of sleep disturbance associated with major depressive disorder?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in the latency of Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in the latency of Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in the latency of Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep It should be a reduction of latency of REM sleep in major depressive disorder.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Options: A, B, & D. Depression is associated with a premature loss of deep (slow-wave) sleep and an increase in nocturnal arousal .

Extraedge:

It is reflected by four types of disturbance : An increase in nocturnal awakenings A reduction in total sleep time Increased phasic rapid eye movement (REM) sleep Increased core body temperature

questions.text: The given EEG pattern demonstrates which stage of sleep
questions.explanation:
Solution:

REM sleep REM sleep - Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity; Saw-tooth waves, theta activity, and slow alpha activity.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Stage I - vertex wave Option: B. Stage II - Low-voltage, mixed frequency background with sleep spindles (1 2-1 4 cps bursts) and K complexes (negative sharp wave followed by positive slow wave) Option: C. Stage III - High amplitude ( more than 75 µV) slow waves (Q cps) occupying 20 to 50 percent of an epoch

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complained of falling asleep during the day for 4 months. She falls asleep two or three times a day while speaking with customers at work. At times, she finds herself falling asleep at her desk and she is awakened when her head hits the computer console in front of her. The most appropriate diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narcolepsy Narcolepsy is a condition characterized by excessive sleepiness , as well as auxiliary symptoms that represent the intrusion of aspects of REM sleep into the waking state.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Circadian rhythm sleep disorder is a sleep disorder caused most often by sleep scheduling changes such as jet lag or night shift work. Option: C. Nightmare disorder is diagnosed in the absence of other predisposing mental illness (e.g., Post Traumatic Stress Disorder) in which the patient has repeated nightmares causing significant distress. Option: D. Primary hypersomnia is excessive daytime drowsiness or hours spent sleeping at night. It is not associated with specific stigmata of narcolepsy such as cataplexy or sleep paralysis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with narcolepsy explains that he has episodes of brief paralysis without any loss of consciousness or other deficits. These attacks are usually precipitated by laughter or anger. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cataplexy Narcolepsy is a sleep disorder . Cataplexy is a transient loss of motor tone , seen in Narcolepsy.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: A. Hypersomnia excessive daytime sleep. Option: C. Hypnagogic hallucinations are vivid dream-like hallucinations occurring in the wake-sleep transition Option: D. Catalepsy is a state of immobility sometimes seen in catatonic states.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes with a chief complaint of not getting enough sleep, problem falling asleep, often wakes up numerous times during the night, and feeling fatigued for the past 2 months. She claims that her sleep problems began after she had an argument on the telephone with her boyfriend. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary insomnia Primary insomnia is diagnosed when the chief complaint is non-restorative sleep or difficulty in initiating or maintaining sleep , and the complaint continues for at least a month . Primary insomnia is often characterized both by difficulty falling asleep and by repeated awakening .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect options:- Option: B. These events usually occur early in the nightly sleep cycle during delta (slow-wave) sleep and the affected person does not remember the episodes in the morning. Option: D.
